I mean I'm well aware of happy hardcore but I feel like there could be a broader umbrella term that could go over that. There's a lot of Eurobeat music I'd put in this category for instance but I wouldn't call it happy hardcore

I really like vaguely cute sounding optimistic cheery techno

I would call this happy hardcore
https://youtu.be/U9iu2iAlps4

But this is firmly eurobeat
https://youtu.be/bWjTR-ccdlg

But also in my heart I believe they should go in the same box somewhere

title: Songs that use Chromatic Mediant chords

last_post.content:
I'm not good enough to figure this out myself. I learned it from Dave Bennett's excellent video on chromatic mediants, which is full of examples:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_8D1F-wIqI

But what's a chromatic mediant? 🤔

'Mediant' just means 'third'. In a chromatic mediant we have two chords, ideally both major triads or both minor triads, that differ by a third and share a note. But what makes it 'chromatic' is that one of these triads is not in the same scale!

(2/n)

We caught up with Richard moulds, the GM of Amazon BraKet - probably the most unusual service in AWS. It's a fully-managed service with APIs for accessing real, live, quantum computers living in cryogenic labs all around the world. https://youtu.be/gFo32NqxorM

What gives Depeche Mode's song Enjoy the Silence that creepy feel?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_G0G1OjM5h0

I just learned one reason: a 'harmonic mediant'. Check out the part at 0:28 where Dave Gahan sings

Words like violence
Break the silence

The first line uses the notes 1 3♭ 5, which form a minor triad. The second uses 3♭ 5♭ 7♭, another minor triad. But while the first chord uses only notes in the minor scale, the second uses one note, 5♭, which is not in that scale!

Creepy!

(1/n)

Tomorrow!
https://youtu.be/gNF4YLPtgfA

1976-77, I roamed the streets as Howard K Martian, extraterrestrial anthropologist. My partner, Jim Neidhardt, put the first portable videocorder (Sony PortaPak) in a backpack and used a telephoto lens. I had a radiomike. People didn't know they were being recorded until we asked them to sign releases.

last_post.content:
"Time Is On My Side" turns 60 this year.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZQN2IfM_eww

Original Kai Winding version was released in October of 1963. It featured vocals by Dionne Warwick, Dee Dee Warwick & Cissy Houston.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eljU_o7zS28

First version with a complete set of lyrics was released in June of 1964. Jimmy Norman finished up the words just before a recording session with Irma Thomas, so she improvised some of the most memorable lines.

title: Relative velocity | Demonstration of constant speed with a moving trampoline

last_post.content:
A nice empirical demonstration of Galileo's principle of relativity: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GIMNS0YiHzY

If one replaces the person on the trampoline with a light beam bouncing up and down between two horizontal mirrors, and assumes that the speed of light is \(c\) in every inertial frame, one obtains (from Pythagoras) the well-known 'light clock" thought experiment of Einstein that derives the fact that such clocks slow down by a factor of √(1−𝑣²/𝑐²) when moving at a velocity \(v\).

The Shadoks.

These strange creatures invaded our televisions in 1968 and were rampant for most of the seventies in 🇫🇷. The opening of the first episod is a cosmographic treatise of the preposterous Shadokean universe!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Les_Shadoks
Full video: https://youtu.be/tpD0Pdr7oD0

#shadoks #shadok #cosmology #universe #popculture #culture #tv #television #ortf #vintage #humour #philisophy #philosophie #dessinanime #lesshadoks #1968 #sixties #seventies #cartoon #cartoons #space #planet #planets

title: How In-Ear Monitors are Making Better Musicians

last_post.content:
Why do orchestras need conductors?

There are various reasons, of course, but here at 0:26 Adam Neely suggests one I hadn't thought about:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mHoljbkyAEs

The speed of light is faster than the speed of sound!

For a large orchestra it can take 0.1 seconds for sound to make a round trip between two performers... and that's a huge amount of time in music. So, get them synched up using light signals instead!

Implementing the Potluck system in LÖVE

https://www.inkandswitch.com/potluck

Research is awesome, but sometimes when you read a paper you just want to add it to your toolbox right now. In a way that fits in with your other tools.

Properties of my tools:

- minimal dependencies (no browser!)
- cross-platform; runs on Windows
- easy for anyone to modify (https://www.inkandswitch.com/end-user-programming)
- live; modify without restarting (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Ab3ArE8W3s)

title: A. Vivaldi: Concerti con molti strumenti [Europa Galante - F. Biondi]

last_post.content:
How would the world be different if Bach's Brandenburg Concerti were lost... or had become popular much earlier?

They were not an unprecedented bolt out of blue. Compare the Concerti con molti strumenti, by Vivaldi:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZgE_x1-kkqY

Similar in some ways! And probably no coincidence: Bach spent time transcribing the works of Vivaldi.

So if the Brandenburg Concerti were lost, maybe we'd spend more time listening to Vivaldi!

(4/n, n = 4)

title: J.S. Bach Brandenburg Concertos  1 - 6, Claudio Abbado

last_post.content:
Listening to the Brandenburg Concerti again, I realized they're a great example of the importance of luck.

Bach dedicated them to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt, hoping to get a job. But Ludwig didn't have enough musicians to play them. Bach didn't get the job. The score was left unused in the Margrave's library until his death.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbQORqkStpk

(1/n)
